occurrences.line_text: And hong adowne his head, as he did dreame:
And all about, the glistring walles were hong
For memorie of which on high there hong
Whilst thus the case in doubtfull ballance hong,
That same aloft he hong in open vew,
For any thing wold slacke, but still vppon him hong.
Hong still vpon his melting mouth attent;
His subtill tongue, like dropping honny, mealt'th
Sweet words, like dropping honny she did shed,
Others sweet words, dropping like honny dew;
After their hiues with honny do abound:
And for Apolloes honor highly herried.
Proud of his dying honor and deare bands,
Now lyest thou of life and honor reft;
To reaue her honor, which she more then life prefard.
To saue her honor from that villaine vild,
But shame of all, that doe for honor striue,
For it of honor and all vertue is
Lest she with blame her honor should attaint,
Nathlesse her honor dearer then her life,
As well became a knight, and did to her all honor.
Which hunt for honor, raised from below,
Thine honor sau'd, though into thraldome throwne?
Wherein the honor both of Armes ye shame,
He would be there, and honor to her spousall ad.
Adorn'd with honor and all comely grace:
And triall, whether should the honor get.
Seeing his honor, which she tendred chiefe,
Haue for more honor brought her to this place,
And as in hate of honorable eld,
And her ador'd by honorable name,
And in the meane vouchsafe her honorable toombe.
Faire marching forth in honorable wize,
Braue be her warres, and honorable deeds,
Sith last I left that honorable place,
Doth beare the fairest flowre in honorable seed.
In braue pursuit of honorable deed,
Had both distaind her honorable blood,
But you, faire Sir, whose honorable sight
In which there dwelt three honorable sages,
And ruled long with honorable state,
Some goodly swayne of honorable place,
Through his Heroicke grace, and honorable gest.
An hundred knights of honorable name
Of th'honorable stage of womanhead,
Redoubted knights, and honorable Dames,
Nought is more honorable to a knight,
By all the names that honorable were.
That made them grow so high t'all honorable hap.
And lifted vp to honorable place,
The knight much honord, as beseemed well,
But both him honor'd as their principall,
Famous through all the world, and honor'd far and nie.
As Arthegall, and Sophy now beene honored.
Come see, where your false Lady doth her honour staine.
With greatest honour he atchieuen might;
For all for prayse and honour he did fight.
Defend thine honour, and thy foes confound:
All in his hand, euen dead we honour should.
But yet more mindfull of his honour deare,
Thy life and honour late aduenturest,
Of chastitie and honour virginall:
Sith that false Traytour did my honour reaue?
And with reprochfull shame mine honour shent,
Of which he honour still away did beare,
Ne thought of honour euer did assay
Such prayse is shame; but honour vertues meed
That mote him honour win, to wreake so foule despight.
All good and honour might therein be red:
And honour in their festiuall resort;
As all the like, which honour haue pursewed
Who seekes with painfull toile, shall honour soonest find.
Who first to rayse our house to honour did begin.
So hast thou oft with guile thine honour blent;
On gallow trees, in honour of his dearest Dame.
Honour, estate, and all this worldes good,
Honour and dignitie from her alone,
Thus for to blot the honour of the dead,
Ne blame your honour with so shamefull vaunt
Or ought that else your honour might maintaine,
Honour is least, where oddes appeareth most.
His honour staines with rancour and despight,
Or dye with honour and desert of fame;
That by well doing sought to honour to aspire.
Ne for them, ne for honour cared hee,
Of all the which they honour euer wonne,
To loose long gotten honour with one euill hond.
To let not others honour be defaste,
Then honour was the meed of victorie,
To crowne his golden lockes with honour dew;
And meet respect of honour put to flight:
And in each gentle hart desire of honour breeds.
Onely for honour and for high regard,
And honour both; for each of other worthy are.
So is his soueraine honour raisde to heauens hight.
And with great honour many battels try:
That to all high desert and honour doth aspire.
And honour of trew Ladies, if ye may
And eke thy selfe of honour, which thou didst atchiue.
To blot her honour, and her heauenly light.
The girlond of her honour did adorne:
And beareth fruit of honour and all chast desire.
She proud of that new honour, which they red,
Of her dew honour was despoyled quight,
So hast thou to thy selfe false honour often wonne.
Bidding them fight for honour of their loue,
And saue her honour with your ventrous paines;
And turne both him and her to honour in this wise.
Assembled, for to get the honour of that game.
And purchase honour in his friends behalue,
Yet euermore his honour he recured,
And eke of honour she did him forestall.
Fro me the honour of that game did reare;
To winne me honour by some noble gest,
In honour of the spousalls, which then were
The honour of the prize should be adiudg'd by those.
Which this dayes honour sau'd to Marinell;
And after fame and honour for to hunt,
Bereaue it thence: such blot his honour blemish should.
That all his other honour ouerthrew.
How to reuenge that blot of honour blent;
And so great honour with so fowle reproch had blent.
And much lesse honour by that warlike kinde
But the braue Prince for honour and for right,
That all her other honour did obscure,
What heauenly Muse shall thy great honour rayse
And yeelding the last honour to her wretched corse.
And forced it, the honour that is dew
As prayse and honour? Or is ought so bright
And honour with indignitie debased:
And foule abusion both his honour blent,
Till it to ripenesse grew, and forth to honour burst.
And flame forth honour in thy noble brest:
Which is the badge of honour and of fame,
But her did honour, and eke many a one
In which all trees of honour stately stood,
But differing in honour and degree:
In th'heart of euery honourable Dame,
And highly honourd in his haughtie eye,
And honourd him, with all that her behoued.
Admyr'd of many, honoured of all,
My dearest Lord fell from high honours staire,
And honours suit my vowed dayes do spend,
And with their honours and their loues regard,
For dread of blame and honours blemishment;
And heauenly honours in the highest place;
Your honours stile, that is your warlike shield.
With fowle words tempring faire, soure gall with hony sweet.
An hony combe, the wakefull dogs espy,
Did raine into her lap an hony dew,
That loue with gall and hony doth abound,
For euery dram of hony therein found,
Like foolish flies about an hony crocke,
Th'other in hers an hony-lady Bee;
She wore much like vnto a Danisk hood
How coul[d]st thou weene, through that disguized hood,
Vnder one hood to shadow faces twaine.
And on his head an hood with aglets sprad,
Ran fierce at me, that fire glaunst from his horses hoofe.
Vnder blake stole hyding her bayted hooke,
In hope her to attaine by hooke or crooke,
Vnwares the hidden hooke with baite I swallowed.
The which her sire had scrap't by hooke and crooke;
But foolish Mayd, whyles heedlesse of the hooke,
Whose top was arm'd with many an yron hooke,
With shepheards hooke in hand, and fit attyre,
In stead of steelehead speare, a shepheards hooke;
He had no weapon, but his shepheards hooke,
And thousand other wayes, to bait his fleshly hookes.
With hookes and ladles, as need did require;
With yron wheeles and hookes arm'd dreadfully,
Amongst the yron hookes and graples keene,
And both with shepheards hookes: But Calidore
Ne car'd to hoord for those, whom he did breede:
To hoord vp heapes of euill gotten masse,
The third, the goodly Barow, which doth hoord
Sith then ye needs will know the griefe I hoord,
In which he found great store of hoorded threasure,
Of liuing bloud yet in her veynes did hop;
And hop'd to reape the crop of all my care,
Long time had lou'd, and hop'd her loue to gaine,
For soueraine hope, which in his helpe he had:
And hope to winne his Ladies heart that day,
There they alight, in hope themselues to hide
Then furthest from her hope, when most she weened nie.
That hope of new good hap he gan to feele;
Her faithfull gard remou'd, her hope dismaid,
From hope of heauen hath thee excluded quight,
Why fearest thou, that canst not hope for thing,
But still twixt feare and hope amazd does sit,
Or euer hope recouer her againe:
But thou his errour shalt, I hope now prouen trew.
In hope to bring her to her last decay.
And said; faire Sir, I hope good hap hath brought
He pluckt from vs all hope of due reliefe,
That nothing may my present hope empare.
In hope to win occasion to his will;
And offred hope of comfort did despise:
In hope to win more fauour with his mate,
Whom they in equall pray hope to deuide,
And of him selfe great hope and helpe conceiu'd,
He gan to hope, of men to be receiu'd
Both feare and hope he in her face did find,
Ne thou for better hope, if thou his presence stay.
Doth promise hope of helpe, and timely grace,
But thou thy treasons fruit, I hope, shalt taste
Gaue him great hart, and hope of victory.
That may not hope by flight to scape aliue,
How may straunge knight hope euer to aspire,
Ye well may hope, and easely attaine?
In hope thereof to win victorious spoile.
Somtimes with threats, somtimes with hope of gaine,
And the sad husbandmans long hope doth throw
But beare him farre from hope of succour vsuall.
Ne stird, till hope of life did him forsake;
In hope her to attaine by hooke or crooke,
Her selfe pursewd, in hope to win thereby
Or euer hope to match in equall fight,
With hope of thing, that may allegge his smart;
For then some hope I might vnto me draw,
Can haue no end, nor hope of my desire,
Both loue and louer, without hope of ioy,
They both conceiuing hope of comfort glad,
Through hope of those, which Merlin had her told
He mote surcease his suit, and lose the hope
Besides all hope with melting eyes did vew,
And so had left them languishing twixt hope and feare.
Vnto the place, to which her hope did guyde,
Was of his forward hope deceiued quight;
In hope vnto my pleasure to haue won;
Without all hope of comfort or reliefe,
Quite of all hope, wherewith he long had fed
And with vaine hope his spirits faint supply,
With him went Hope in rancke, a handsome Mayd,
Now gan to feede on hope, which she before
Hope to endure, sith workes of heauenly wits
Most confidence and hope of happie speed,
In hope to take him prisoner, where he stood on ground.
They were full glad, in hope themselues to get her:
And feeble hope hung all this while suspence,
Its best to hope the best, though of the worst affrayd.
Yet found no ease of griefe, nor hope of grace,
For losse of her new loue, the hope of her desire.
And pant with hope of that aduentures hap:
Through which some lost great hope vnheedily,
Excludes from fairest hope, withouten further triall.
In hope thereby her to his bent to draw:
To hope (quoth he) him soone to ouertake,
That there mote be no hope of reparation,
In hope by him great benefite to gaine,
Which to her in that daunger hope of life did offer.
In hope ye will not turne misfortune to my blame
Would to his hope a windowe open wyde,
That will not take the offer of good hope,
But drew him on with hope, fit leasure to awayt.
Whereat her heart was fild with hope and drede;
But will my cares vnfolde, in hope to find
The care whereof, and hope of his successe
In hope to haue her ouerhent at last:
With gladfull hast, in hope of him to get
In hope some stroke to fasten on him neare;
Should issue forth, in hope to find some spoyle,
And so would hope him easily to foyle.
With hope of her some wishfull boot to haue.
And both with hope of shadowes vaine inspyred.)
For other meede may hope for none of mee,
With hope of helpe in that her greatest neede.
Where they may hope a kingdome to obtaine.
Yet now some hope your words vnto me add.
Vnto this shame, and my young hope subuert,
His hope of refuge vsed to remaine.
How can he mercy euer hope to haue?
I neuer saw in any greater hope appeare.
For the rare hope which in his yeares appear'd,
In hope he sure would proue a doughtie knight:
Is this the hope that to my hoary heare
Such is the weakenesse of all mortall hope;
In hope there for his loue some succour to prouyde.
Twixt darkenesse dread, and hope of liuing light,
To send her succour, being of all hope forlore.
At length, when as no hope of his retourne
In vaine of me ye hope for remedie,
What hope of helpe doth then for vs remaine,
Ne powre had to withstand, ne hope of any ayd.
To hope for to release or mollify;
And gaue his foe good hope of victory.
Which gaue him hope, and did him halfe perswade,
In hope there newes to learne, how they mote best assay.
Hope to escape his venemous despite,
For hoped loue to winne me certaine hate?
But ere my hoped day of spousall shone,
To muse on meanes of hoped victory.
Her hoped pray, she would no lenger bide,
Well hoped I, and faire beginnings had,
Which when he felt to moue, he hoped faire
Well hoped he, ere long that hardy guest,
Far from the hoped hauen of reliefe,
Well hoped she the beast engor'd had beene,
The greedy villein from his hoped pray,
For well they hoped to haue got great good,
Who haplesse, and eke hopelesse, all in vaine
Then hopelesse hartlesse, gan the cunning thiefe
From whence descend all hopelesse remedies:
Thus am I hopelesse euer to attaine
Her freed, in which ye her all hopelesse left,
With that, like one that hopelesse was repryu'd
Vnhappie Knight, vpon whose hopelesse state
I will it graunt, your hopelesse life to saue;
With idle hopes, which them doe entertaine,
On which he safety hopes, that earst feard to be lost.
Yet hoping griefe may lessen being told,
Then hoping that the change of aire and place
Hoping thereby to haue my loue obtayned:
Hoping vnto some refuge to withdraw:
Well hop't he then, when this was propheside,
Vnder the steepe foot of a mountaine hore;
Vnder the foot of Rauran mossy hore,
Through wisedome of a matrone graue and hore;
Sunning his threasure hore:
Tho hauing vewd a while the surges hore,
An aged sire with head all frory hore,
And trode downe in the durt, where his hore beard
Did tricle downe her haire, like to the hore
Doth frie with fome aboue the surges hore.
Then tooke that Squire an horne of bugle small,
At last they heard a horne, that shrilled cleare
When first I heard her horne sound with such ghastlinesse.
Which was the cause, when earst that horne I heard,
His precious horne, sought of his enimies
And wind his horne vnder the castle wall,
On her they poured forth of plenteous horne;
And eke the Bull hath with his bow-bent horne
And by his side his hunters horne he hanging had.
Their horned fronts so fierce on either side
And with their horned feet do weare the ground,
And with their horned feet the greene grasse wore,
So home he marcht emongst the horned heard,
But till the horned moone three courses did expire.
Their frowning forheads with rough hornes yclad,
Of that same hornes great vertues weren told,
And thrise three times had fild her crooked hornes,
But with his dreadfull hornes them driues afore,
With gilden hornes, and flowry girlonds crownd,
That through the helpe of his faire hornes on hight,
Who butted him with hornes on euery syde,
A saluage Bull, whose cruell hornes doe threat
Then gan the bagpypes and the hornes to shrill,
And threats his horns, and bellowes like the thonder,
In th'Horoscope of her natiuitee,
Vpon his foe, a Dragon horrible and stearne.
A floud of poyson horrible and blacke,
Then choosing out few wordes most horrible,
An hideous Geant horrible and hye,
An huge great Dragon horrible in sight,
With that fire-mouthed Dragon, horrible and bright?
His body monstrous, horrible, and vast,
So huge and horrible a masse it seem'd;
With horrible assault, and furie fell,
Which when I heard, with horrible affright
Deformed creatures, horrible in sight,
But the fift troupe most horrible of hew,
That seem'd more horrible then hell to bee,
Most vgly shapes, and horrible aspects,
The horrible Sea-satyre, that doth shew
O horrible enchantment, that him so did blend.
Yet did possesse their horrible intent:
An hideous beast, of horrible aspect,
With shoure and hayle so horrible and dred,
Of stature huge, and horrible of hew,
Vpon a rocke with horrible dismay,
Seem'd to awake in horrible dismay,
Of horrible aspect, and dreadfull mood,
Horrible, hideous, and of hellish race,
And bitter curses, horrible to tell,
Gan cry aloud with horrible affright,
And fared like a feend, right horrible in hew.
He gaz'd about, and stared horriblie,
Halfe like a serpent horribly displaide,
And horribly misshapes with vgly sightes,
Horribly then he gan to rage, and rayle,
Whose carcases on ground were horribly prostrate.
From vnder that deepe Rocke most horribly rebounds.
And on them layd so huge and horribly,
And roring horribly, did him compell
Did often tremble at his horrid vew,
His haughtie helmet, horrid all with gold,
Priuily moystening his horrid cheek.
And with that suddein horror could no member moue.
And rusticke horror all a side doe lay,
That suddeine horror to faint harts did show;
Had wrought that horror strange, and dar'd his dreaded powre.
That to haue heard, great horror would haue bred,
Whiles trembling horror did his conscience dant,
Which sinfull horror workes in wounded hart,
That all the land with stench, and heauen with horror choke.
And carries into smoake with rage and horror great.
Halfe in a maze with horror hideous,
Whose hideous horror and sad trembling sound
Foule horror, and eke hellish dreriment:
Which all the forrest did with horror fill:
Yet in that horror shewd a seemely grace,
That horror gan the virgins hart to perse,
And in the midst thereof did horror dwell,
Or bide the horror of his wreakfull hand,
And aggrauate the horror of her blame.
And for more horror and more crueltie,
Who in the horror of the griesly night,
In hatefull darkenesse and in deepe horrore,
With hideous horrour both together smight,
And stony horrour all her sences fild
And trembling horrour ran through euery ioynt,
That horrour made to all, that did behold;
And scared nations doest with horrour sterne astownd.
That with their horrour heauen and earth did ring,
So shaked he, that horrour was to heare,
Ah God, what horrour and tormenting griefe
Deadly dismayd, with horrour of that dint
And was with dread and horrour compassed around.
And ouer them sad Horrour with grim hew,
Doth dim with horrour and deformitie,
Which suddeine horrour and confused cry,
Vnweeting, what such horrour straunge did reare.
All those, and all that else does horrour breed,
Through ghastly horrour, and eternall shade;
And euery daintie limbe with horrour shake;
Halfe of thy dayes doest lead in horrour hideous.
Trembling with horrour, as that did foresee
And with sterne horrour backward gan to start:
Where he through priuy griefe, and horrour vaine,
And dreadfull horrour did all entraunce choke,
Straunge horrour, to deforme his griesly shade;
Whilest trembling horrour did his sense assayle,
But darknesse and dread horrour, where she dwelt,
For horrour of his shamefull villany.
Lay hid in horrour of eternall night?
And their faint harts with senselesse horrour queld,
And horrour of fowle death for Knight vnfit,
And hell vnto him selfe with horrour great.
To whom for endlesse horrour of his shame,
To hide the horrour, which did lurke behinde,
Who with the horrour of her haplesse care
In hideous horrour and obscurity,
So bent his speare, and spurnd his horse with yron heele.
With his long tayle, that horse and man to ground did rush.
Both horse and man vp lightly rose againe,
Snatcht vp both horse & man, to beare them quite away.
horse is made the scorne
Both horse and man nigh able for to choke;
On his horse necke before the quilted sell,
That horse and man it made to reele aside;
With stedfast hand vpon his horse did stay,
From her dull horse, in desperate distresse,
There well perceiu'd he, that it was the horse,
Lying athwart her horse in great distresse,
Or helpe himselfe, and laying thwart her horse,
Hard is to teach an old horse amble trew.
They rudely droue to ground both man and horse,
And like a winged horse he tooke his flight,
Each other horse and man to ground did send;
But horse and foote knew Diamond to wield:
That on an heape were tumbled horse and man.
That horse and man to ground he quite did beare,
And rudely tumbling downe vnder his horse feete fell.
That to the ground she smote both horse and man;
The Ladies both on horse, together fast embraced.
That horse and man he equally dismaies,
Throughout the hall, for that same warlike horse.
His horse purloyned was by subtill traine:
The horse in hand, within his mouth to looke:
That vnto him the horse belong'd, and sayd;
Hence fare on foot, till he an horse haue gayned.
It had himselfe transfixed, or his horse,
But he them ouerthrew both man and horse,
But rudely rowld to ground both man and horse,
On her faire feet by his horse side did pas
Both horse and armes, and what so else to lend,
Whipping her horse, did with his smarting toole
This was Disdaine, who led that Ladies horse
They reared him on horsebacke, and vpstayd,
On horsebacke vsed Triamond to fight,
To proue if better foote then horsebacke would ensew.
Against an armed knight, that did on horsebacke ryde.
The knight, as ye did see, on horsebacke was,
The other downe vnder their horses feete,
Ouer his horses taile aboue a stryde:
Till on her horses hinder parts it fell;
Ran fierce at me, that fire glaunst from his horses hoofe.
His horses backe, for dread of being drownd,
Shapt like a horses shoe, who list to seeke it there.
His horses backe, yet to and fro long shooke,
Vnto his horses gaue his guests for meat,
Or vnder his fierce horses feet haue borne
Gaue way vnto his horses speedie flying,
And comming full before his horses vew,
And lighting on his horses head, him quite did mall.
Tooke surer hould, and from his horses backe
Hengist and Horsus, well approu'd in warre,
He was an aged syre, all hory gray,
Of vile vngentlenesse, or hospitages breach.
Which choosing for that euenings hospitale,
